Graphical abstract A series of bimetallic Pd–Ag catalysts supported on the carbon material Sibunit was synthesized for selective liquid-phase acetylene hydrogenation. Using XRD and EXAFS it was shown that palladium and silver in the 0.5% Pd–Ag/Sibunit can form bimetallic Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoparticles with the composition depending on the Pd:Ag ratio. The active component of Pd–Ag(1:0.25)/Sibunit, Pd–Ag(1:1)/Sibunit and Pd–Ag(1:4)/Sibunit is represented by the particles of Pd0.74Ag0.26, Pd0.60Ag0.40 and Pd0.41Ag0.59 nanoalloys, respectively. An increase of the quantity of silver decreases the catalyst activity. The XPS study revealed that this phenomenon is caused by a decrease in the surface concentration of palladium (geometrical effect) and an increase in the degree of palladium electronic modification with silver (electronic effect). The latter exerts a beneficial effect on the reaction selectivity: as the Pd:Ag molar ratio is raised to 1:2, selectivity to ethylene increases to 81% (X > 97%), which exceeds 2.7-fold the selectivity of Pd/Sibunit. Keywords Palladium catalyst Modification with Ag Nanoparticles Structural changes Acetylene hydrogenation 1 Introduction The production of ethylene is a topical task because this compound serves as the initial feedstock for petrochemical polymerization processes and is used also to obtain various industrial products, such as acetaldehyde, ethylene oxide, acetic acid, and others [1,2]. Some promising pilot production technologies make it possible to obtain ethylene by processing of natural and associated gases, in particular, the process developed by Synfuels [3,4] for the conversion of natural gas to liquid hydrocarbons (GTL technology) and/or ethylene (GTE technology). Main steps of the process include high-temperature oxidative pyrolysis of natural gas, absorption of acetylene by a solvent, selective liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene, and oligomerization of ethylene yielding motor fuel components. Catalysts for hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene are represented now by supported palladium. However, due to insufficient selectivity and rapid deactivation of such monometallic system, it is necessary to find ways for improving its properties [5,6]. According to the literature, the yield of the target product can be increased by selection of the optimal support or modification of its properties [7–10], elaboration of the catalyst synthesis method [11–13], introduction of gaseous additives into reaction medium, such as nitrous bases, sulfur-containing compounds or CO [6,14–16], or introduction of a modifying element [17–21]. The effect of a modifier is commonly attributed to geometrical [13,22] or electronic [12,13,23] factors. The geometrical factor implies intercalation of a modifier into the palladium matrix, which leads to a decrease in the number of polyatomic sites of palladium that are responsible for dissociative adsorption of acetylene and formation of palladium hydride. In the case of electronic factor, a modifier is used to dope electrons to the vacancies that are formed on d-orbitals of palladium. Both factors enhance the selectivity of the target product formation; however, they strongly decrease the catalyst activity [24]. Silver is among the most efficient modifying metals. Pd–Ag alloyed catalysts are widely used in the industrially important gas-phase processes for hydrogenation of acetylene impurity in ethylene obtained by the pyrolysis of heavy hydrocarbons [9,17,25,26]. Besides, recent publications indicate that Pd–Ag catalysts are efficient in the liquid-phase processes [27–29]. The properties of Pd–Ag systems are primarily determined by the structure of bimetallic nanoparticles. Metals can interact both with the formation of bimetallic nanoalloys [27,30] or core-shell structures [29,31,32] and with the formation of boundary interfaces between individual components [11,33]. Therewith, the composition of nanoalloys can vary in a wide range because palladium and silver are able to form a system with continuous mutual solubility of components [34]. The literature provides different data on the optimal composition of bimetallic Pd–Ag nanoparticles for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. It is known that commercial Pd–Ag catalysts for the removal of acetylene impurity from pyrolytic ethylene contain a great excess of a modifier with the Pd:Ag weight ratio between 1:10 and 1:2 [8,35]. A recent publication [12] devoted to Pd–Ag/SiO2 catalysts for the gas-phase removal of acetylene traces (1 vol.%) from ethylene (20 vol.%) confirmed that the highest efficiency was observed for the samples containing a large excess of modifier (5 wt.%) over palladium, the content of which was at the ppm level (168–1016 ppm). The FTIR study revealed that the steps of joint impregnation of the support from solutions of individual salts and its reduction in hydrogen at 400 °C led to the formation of the so-called single-atom catalysts, which are highly selective due to facilitated activation of acetylene and weak adsorption of the target olefin. It was shown that the necessity of introducing a large excess of modifier was caused by the ability of silver to segregation and formation of -Ag–Pd–Ag- fragments with single palladium atoms [36]. At the same time, in [8] the best Pd:Ag weight ratio for the gas-phase conversion of acetylene to ethylene (14 vol.% C2H2 and 85.7 vol.% H2) over 0.02%Pd–Ag/LSA–SiO2 catalyst was found to be 1:1. A further introduction of silver up to the Pd:Ag ratio of 1:3 was accompanied by a decrease in activity at a constant selectivity. Therewith, an efficient suppression of the green oil formation was demonstrated for the catalyst with equal loading of metals. The content of green oil in the reaction products was not higher than 2% at 230 °C. Similarly, in [37] high efficiency of 1%Pd–Ag/Al2O3 catalysts in hydrogenation of acetylene (1 vol.%) to ethylene was achieved even upon introduction of small amounts of silver. Increasing the modifier content to the atomic ratio Pd:Ag = 1:1, the authors observed an enhancement of the process selectivity. It should be noted that modern scientific and patent literature describes the application of supported Pd–Ag catalysts for purification of ethylene from acetylene impurity (<2 vol.%) mostly in the gas phase. Only some patents [3,4] consider such systems in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of mixtures of the products from oxidative pyrolysis of methane, which have a higher concentration of acetylene (> 2 vol.%); in this case, the composition of the reaction gas mixture promotes the reactions of exhaustive hydrogenation (because hydrogen as the main component of the gas mixture) and oligomerization (there is a high content of acetylene in the mixture). Our earlier publications demonstrated the possibility to form bimetallic nanoalloy in the 0.5%Pd–0.5%Ag/C catalyst, supported on carbon material Sibunit, which showed high selectivity in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene [38,39]. So the aim of the present work is to continue the investigation of Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts, particularly, to elucidate the effect of the Pd:Ag molar ratio on the composition and structure of the active component and catalytic properties of Pd–Ag/Sibunit in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene. Sibunit is a carbon black/pyrocarbon composite produced by the pyrolysis of light hydrocarbons on a carbon black template followed by the steam activation of the resulting composite [40]. The unique characteristics of the Sibunit carbon such as thermal and chemical stability, high mechanical stiffness, high purity and the variable textural characteristics likes of surface area, pore size distribution, agglomerate size and shape make these material attractive for use as catalysts support. In comparison with conventional supports (for example, Al2O3), Sibunit does not contain acid sites facilitating acetylene oligomerization, the products of which block the active surface of the catalyst and decrease the catalytic activity [41,42]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Sibunit mesoporous carbon material with a specific surface area SBET ∼336 m2/g was used as a support for the catalysts. The initial granules with the diameter of 2 mm were carefully washed with water, dried at 120 °C for 6 h, and ground to fine powder. The study was performed using the Sibunit fraction with the particle size from 0.07 to 0.09 mm, which was pretreated by a 5% solution of HNO3 as was described in [43]. The modified Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation from an aqueous solution containing both the palladium and silver nitrates. The unmodified Pd/Sibunit sample was synthesized by a similar method, but the impregnating solution contained only Pd(NO3)2. The obtained samples were dried at room temperature for 24 h (in darkness) and then reduced in flowing hydrogen (60 mL/min) at 500 °C for 5 h. The heating and cooling rates were 10 °C/min. The resulting catalysts contained 0.5 wt.% Pd. The Pd:Ag molar ratio was varied in a range from 1:0.25 to 1:4. The samples were stored in an desiccator in a helium atmosphere to prevent their contact with air. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Phase composition of the catalysts was studied by powder X-ray diffraction on a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer using monochromatic Cu-Kα radiation. The following modes were employed: a scanning step of 0.020, accumulation time 2 s/points, voltage 40 kV, and filament current 40 mA. The scanning range was 20–90° 2Θ. The obtained diffraction patterns were interpreted using the powder diffraction database ICDD, PDF-2 (2006). Palladium K-edge and silver K-edge X-ray absorption spectra were measured at the station of Structural Materials Science of the Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source (National Research Center “Kurchatov Institute”, Moscow, Russia). All the spectra were obtained in transmission mode. The procedure of experiment and the methods used for processing of experimental spectra were reported in our earlier study [38]. Simulation of EXAFS spectra was performed in R-space. The model included single scattering paths in the range of interatomic distances from 1.2–3.0 Å. Interatomic distance R (Å), Debye–Waller factor σ2 (Å2), and coordination number (CN) were used as the fitting parameters. The spectrum of bulk metallic palladium (foil), which served as a standard, was recorded under the same conditions as the spectra of samples under consideration. Data on silver foil were taken from the database [44]. X-ray photoelectron spectra were measured on a photoelectron spectrometer SPECS (Germany) using an AlKα source (hν =1486.6 eV, 150 W). The binding energy (BE) scale was preliminarily calibrated by positions of the peaks of gold and copper core levels: Au4f7/2 – 84.0 eV and Cu2p3/2 – 932.67 eV. During the measurements, the pressure of residual gases did not exceed 8 × 10–9 mbar. Dispersed powder samples were rubbed in the stainless steel mesh that was spot-welded on a standard sample-holder. Before measurements, the catalysts were treated in a high-pressure cell of spectrometer in a hydrogen medium (p = 300 mbar) at 450 °C for 60 min, after which (without air contact) they were transferred to the analytical chamber, and photoelectron spectra were recorded. To estimate the chemical (charge) state of elements on the surface of samples narrow C1s, Pd3d, Ag3d, and O1s regions were measured. The positions of measured spectra were corrected using the C1s core level (BE = 284.5 eV) from carbon in the composition of support. The relative content of elements on the surface of samples and the ratio of their atomic concentrations were determined from the integrated intensities of photoelectron lines corrected by their respective atomic sensitivity factors [45]. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests were performed on a setup for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene in a flow mode at atmospheric pressure. A catalyst sample (50.0 mg) was placed in the non-gradient temperature-controlled shaker-type flow reactor (swinging frequency 7–8 s–1) [15]. N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (8.0 mL) was used as a solvent which has a high capacity for acetylene and a much lower ability to dissolve ethylene and other products of the reaction [46]. Catalytic testing was carried out over the temperature range of 25−95 °C. The initial reaction mixture was formed by mixing the streams of components: 4 vol.% C2H2 and 96 vol.% H2. The total flow rate of the reaction mixture was 100 mL/min. The composition of the reaction products mixture (the gaseous part) was determined using a Chromos GH-1000 gas chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (25 m × 0.32 mm, SiO2 as a stationary phase, the operating temperature of 60 °C) and a flame-ionization detector. Nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. Sampling was made each 35 min. The conversion of acetylene (X,%), the selectivity to ethylene ( S C 2 H 4 ,%) and ethane ( S C 2 H 6 ,%) were calculated from areas of the corresponding peaks by the normalization method. The selectivity to oligomers ( S ∑ C 4 + ,%) was calculated based on a carbon balance. The activity referred to 1 g of catalyst (ml (C2H2)/(gcat min)) was estimated as follows: W k = V m i x ∙ C 0 ∙ X C 2 H 2 , % m c a t ∙ 100 where Vmix is the feed space velocity, ml/min; C 0 – the initial concentration of C2H2 in the reaction mixture flow, ml (C2H2)/mL gas mixture; mcat – the weight of the catalyst sample, g. The yield of ethylene (Y) was calculated by the formula: Y C 2 H 4 = X × S C 2 H 4 / 100 A preliminary study showed that Sibunit and 0.5 wt.% silver deposited on it are inactive in the reaction under consideration. The results of catalytic experiments are characterized by a good reproducibility. The coefficient of variation for determining the catalytic parameters does not exceed 2%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance of Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts Results of the catalytic testing of the 0.5%Pd/Sibunit catalyst and the modified 0.5%Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene are illustrated in Fig. 1 . As can be seen the monometallic catalyst provided the highest conversion of acetylene, whereas the silver-containing samples were less active. The introduction of silver and an increase of its amount from Pd:Ag = 1:0.25 to Pd:Ag = 1:4 was accompanied by a gradual shift of conversion curves toward high temperatures. The point on the curve corresponding to X = 50% shifted from 27 °C for Pd/Sibunit to 76 °C for Pd–Ag(1:4)/Sibunit. Overall, the catalytic activity (referred to unit catalyst weight) decreased linearly with increasing the amount of modifier in the sample (Fig. 1b). When plotting the conversion curves, it was found that selectivity of the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene on the 0.5%Pd/Sibunit catalyst and modified 0.5%Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples remained constant until acetylene conversion reached ∼80%. The distribution of products changed at higher conversions. For 0.5%Pd/Sibunit, this showed up as a decrease in selectivity to the target product and oligomers at a simultaneous increase in the yield of ethane that is the product of complete acetylene hydrogenation. At the acetylene conversion above 85–90%, the distribution of products stabilized and remained approximately constant. In this connection, Fig. 1c and d display data on the selectivity to ethane, ethylene and oligomers in dependence on the content of modifier at 25 °C, when acetylene conversion for all the samples does not exceed 50%, and at 85 °C, when acetylene conversion is above 85%. As shown in Fig. 1c, raising the silver content to Pd:Ag = 1:0.5–1:2 was accompanied by an increase in the amount of produced ethylene from 68% (on Pd/Sibunit) to 79–81% due to a decrease in the ethane fraction in the reaction products. Therewith, the sample containing an excess of modifier Pd:Ag = 1:4 showed a loss in selectivity due to the growing contribution of oligomerization processes. Along with this, an essential characteristic of the catalyst is its ability to maintain high selectivity at a complete conversion of the substrate. According to Fig. 1d, for Pd/Sibunit at 85 °C, the prevailing product of the reaction was ethane. Selectivity to ethane reached 64%, which was more than twofold higher as compared to the ethylene selectivity ( S C 2 H 4 = 31%). The effect of modification with silver was more pronounced under the indicated conditions. An increase in the amount of modifier to Pd:Ag = 1:2 resulted in a sharp growth of selectivity to ethylene up to 81%, so that the amount of the target ethylene exceeded more than fivefold the amount of undesirable ethane. A further introduction of silver up to Pd:Ag = 1:4 also led to an increase in the amount of hydrooligomerization products. According to [6,47], the growth of selectivity for alloyed Pd–Ag catalysts is related to changes in adsorption characteristics of the surface due to modification. Thus, the DFT calculations reported in [47] demonstrated that on the surface of bimetallic particle the metal-adsorbate bond strength became weaker for hydrocarbon intermediates. In particular, the chemisorption energy of the surface vinyl intermediate, which is the precursor of ethylene, changes from 274 kJ/mol on the Pd(111) face to 214 kJ/mol on the surface of Pd50%–Ag50% alloy. Such weakening of the adsorption strength facilitate the ethylene desorption and cause the increase of the process selectivity. Ag enhances the desorption of both ethylene and hydrogen from the surface thus limiting their ability to undergo subsequent reactions. A comparison of data obtained in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene with the literature data on the properties of supported Pd–Ag catalysts in the gas-phase acetylene hydrogenation allows to conclude the general similarity of the regularities concerning the decrease in activity and the growth of selectivity with raising the silver content [8,41]. Thus, in [8] it was shown for 0.02%Pd–Ag/LSA–SiO2 that an increase in the amount of silver to Pd:Ag = 1 causes an increase in ethylene selectivity, but leads to a decrease in activity. It should be noted that the common feature of the modified Pd–Ag/Sibunit systems containing equimolar or excessive with respect to palladium amount of silver is their ability to maintain high selectivity to the target product even at a high conversion of acetylene >80% (Fig. 1e) and, accordingly, high and stable yield of the target product (Fig. 1f). According to Fig. 1f, as the silver amount is increased, the ethylene yield grows and its maximum shifts toward higher temperatures. For unmodified Pd/Sibunit catalyst, the highest yield of ethylene equal to 59% was reached at 35 °C. Among the modified samples, the maximum value of Y C 2 H 4 equal to 79% was observed for Pd–Ag(1:2)/Sibunit at the reaction temperature of 95 °C. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts 3.2.1 X-ray diffraction analysis According to the literature data, the formation of bimetallic Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoalloys may occur in supported Pd–Ag systems [17,48–50]. The geometry and electronic properties of active sites in the modified samples should substantially differ from those of unmodified palladium and provide high selectivity of the hydrogenation of triple bonds to double ones [9,12,37]. X-ray diffraction analysis was used to determine the composition of nanoparticles formed in the Pd–Ag/Sibunit systems under consideration, which was necessary for interpretation of catalytic data. To ensure more reliable identification of phases, samples were synthesized with the molar ratio Pd:Ag equal to 1:0.25, 1:1 and 1:4, but with a higher absolute content of palladium and modifier, according to recommendations in the literature [51]. The Pd content was 7 wt.%. For a more correct comparison, diffraction patterns of the 7%Pd/Sibunit catalyst and the oxidized support (without deposited metals) treated in H2 at 500 °C were also recorded. The obtained diffraction patterns are displayed in Fig. 2 . Reflections from the carbon substrate (the size of a carbon package along с axis is L c = 34−36 Å) were found for all the catalysts. Metallic palladium crystallites are characterized by the appearance of diffraction peaks at 40°, 47°, 68° and 81°, which correspond to (111), (200), (220) and (311) faces, respectively (ICSD № 41517, Fm-3m space group, i.e. face-centered cubic lattice). The indicated signals were identified only for monometallic Pd/Sibunit catalyst. Diffraction patterns of the metallic silver phase were observed for the Ag/Sibunit sample. The corresponding reflections showed up at 38° (111), 44° (200), 64° (220), 77° (311) and 82° (222) 2ʘ (ICSD № 426921, also Fm-3 m space group, but with larger value of lattice constant; see Table 1 ). The introduction of silver into Pd/Sibunit and the increase in its amount from Pd:Ag = 1:0.25 to 1:4 gradually changed the positions of main reflections of metallic palladium, which led to a shift toward low 2ʘ diffraction angles. It is known that palladium-silver systems are characterized by continuous mutual solubility of components [34] and form a series of solid solutions with the face-centered cubic lattice, the parameter of which is related to the composition of solid solution [34]. Hence, the shift observed in the diffraction patterns testifies to the formation of Pd–Ag nanoalloys with different composition [27,28,30,31,52]. The composition of the formed phases was calculated by the Vegard’s law from the measured lattice parameters [53]. As shown in Table 1, the Pd0.74Ag0.26 bimetallic nanoparticles enriched with palladium are formed in the Pd–Ag(1:0.25)/Sibunit sample. In the sample with equimolar ratio of components Pd:Ag = 1:1, the composition of particles approached Pd0.60Ag0.40. A further introduction of the excess amount of silver with respect to palladium (Pd:Ag = 1:4) was accompanied by the formation of silver-enriched Pd0.41Ag0.59 nanoalloy. Fig. 3 illustrates the dependence of FCC lattice parameter on the amount of silver in the sample. It is seen that structural parameters of the nanoalloys take intermediate values between those typical of its individual components – metallic palladium and silver. It should be noted that deviation of the nanoalloy composition from equimolar for the Pd–Ag(1:1)/Sibunit sample is related to the formation of large metallic silver particles (CSRAg =11.3 nm) in this system, which may emerge due to reduction of silver nitrate to the Ag metal during the deposition and drying. Even larger silver particles (with the twofold greater diameter) were detected in Pd–Ag(1:4)/Sibunit. Therewith, crystallites of bimetallic phase had a much higher dispersion irrespective of the Pd:Ag ratio. The CSR size for Pd x Ag(1− x ) was 4.4–4.7 nm (Table 1). It is possible that the catalysts also contain a certain amount of nanodispersed metallic palladium, which is not detected by the XRD method. Thus, according to XRD data, palladium-silver nanoalloys are formed in the model 7%Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts; the composition of the alloy particles widely varies and is determined primarily by the chosen molar ratio of Pd to Ag that is used in the synthesis of samples. 3.2.2 EXAFS spectroscopy Extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS) was employed to compare XRD data on the composition of active component that were obtained for the model 7%Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples with the data on active component of the catalysts that are used for the tests in acetylene hydrogenation and have the smaller palladium (0.5 wt.%) and modifier content. This method gives the averaged information on the local environment of all absorbing atoms of specific type and, in distinction to XRD, makes it possible to analyze nanodispersed systems containing both the crystallized and amorphous phases. Fourier transforms of Pd K-edge and Ag K-edge EXAFS spectra for the modified samples are displayed in Fig. 4 ; the results of structural analysis are listed in Table 2 . Data on the structure of supported particles in monometallic 0.5%Pd/Sibunit catalyst were obtained earlier and reported in our previous publication [54]. The active component of this system is represented by fine particles of zero-valent palladium with smaller CN and Pd-Pd interatomic distances as compared to the bulk metal (ICSD № 41517), which may be caused by a small size of the synthesized particles (CSRPd = 6.6 nm) [11]. The feature of Pd–Ag systems that complicates the analysis of EXAFS spectra is the presence of two types of atoms – 46Pd and 47Ag, which have close photoelectron scattering amplitudes and phase shifts and therefore are almost indistinguishable for EXAFS. In addition, metallic palladium and silver have identical crystal structure (FCC lattice); however, the difference in the lattice constant is relatively large: close values of the lattice constant a =3.89 Å (Pd) and a =4.09 Å (Ag), and distances between the nearest adjacent atoms Pd–Pd 2.75 Å and Ag–Ag 2.95 Å (ICSD № 41517 and ICSD № 426921). Therefore, if together with solid solution a significant amount of monometallic phase is formed, EXAFS fit reveals the splitting of the first coordination sphere. The ARD curve of palladium K-edge for 0.5%Pd–Ag(1:0.25)/Sibunit sample is simulated by a single Pd-Pd distance. This scattering path is characterized by an increased interatomic distance R Pd−Pd = 2.76 Å as compared to a similar distance in the reference sample Pd/Sibunit (R Pd−Pd = 2.72). This feature may testify to the presence of a weakly pronounced interaction between palladium and silver in the catalyst under study [11]. The proposed hypothesis is confirmed by the analysis of the Ag K-edge spectrum: the model includes the Ag–Ag and Ag–Pd scattering paths of metallic silver and bimetallic compound with R Ag−Pd = 2.80, respectively. However, since the Ag–Pd interatomic distance is measured with high error, the composition of Pd x Ag(1− x ) particles cannot be calculated with a desired accuracy. High CNAg−Pd for silver K-edge indicates the prevalence of bimetallic bonds over monometallic. At the same time, the increased value of Debye-Waller factor (0.0105 Å2) may indicate that intercalation of silver leads to a strong structural disorder of the palladium crystal lattice. For interpretation the EXAFS data of bimetallic catalysts with a high content of modifier, joint modeling of palladium K-edge and silver K-edge spectra was performed in order to reduce the number of independently refined parameters and to consider more correctly the mutual correlations. Thereby, parameters characterizing the same structural features in models for different edges, particularly, Pd–Ag and Ag–Pd interatomic distances and Debye–Waller factors, were equated to each other. An increase in the silver content of catalyst to equimolar (Pd:Ag = 1:1) significantly changes the positions of electron density maxima on the ARD curves of both the Pd K-edge and Ag K-edge (Fig. 4) and testifies to changes in the local environment of both metals. According to the fitting data, bimetallic Pd–Ag scattering paths with interatomic distances 2.80 Å prevail in the sample; they correspond to nanoparticles with the composition Pd0.6Ag0.4 and agree well with XRD data for the model catalyst. It should be noted that a decrease in Debye–Waller factor for the Pd–Ag path with an increase in Pd:Ag ratio from 1:0.25 to 1:1 may be caused by structural ordering of bimetallic compound. The introduction of an excess amount of modifier into the catalyst (Pd:Ag = 1:4) is accompanied by a further increase in the lattice parameters of palladium. Bimetallic nanophase formed in this sample is characterized by an increase in the distance between adjacent Pd and Ag atoms in the joint FCC lattice to 2.85 Å, which evidences that bimetallic phase is enriched with the silver component and its composition approaches Pd0.35Ag0.65. The sample contains also a small amount of palladium particles with the increased R Pd−Pd (2.78 Å). Overall, the results of EXAFS analysis of 0.5%Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples are consistent with the XRD data obtained for the model 7%Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts. A comparison with the catalytic data allows to conclude that the composition of alloyed Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoparticles strongly affects the catalytic properties of Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples in the tested reaction. This is probably due to the geometric effect of modification, expressed in the “dilution” of neighboring palladium atoms by silver, which affects the shape and strength of acetylene adsorption [2,24,37,55]. To confirm this assumption, it is important to know whether such “dilution” occurs on the catalyst surface, since the surface of the active component directly interacts with the reactants and participates in the catalytic reaction. In addition, along with the geometrical effect, essential is the contribution of electronic component of modification, i.e. the ability of silver to compensate the excessive positive charge emerging on highly dispersed palladium atoms [34,55,56]. The donation of electron density from silver atom to unfilled d-orbitals of palladium should suppress the affinity of the latter for sorption of unsaturated compounds, particularly, the green oil oligomers, which block the active surface and lead to catalyst deactivation [13,57]. This should considerably facilitate the ethylene desorption, which prevents its complete hydrogenation to ethane. It is known that electron density in metallic palladium can be redistributed from 4d to the free 5s-sublevel; as a result, its 4d-orbitals contain ∼0.38–0.6 vacancies per atom [34]. Since the Fermi level of Ag is above the Fermi level of Pd, s-electrons can pass from the IB-subgroup metal to vacant d-orbitals of palladium up to ca. 38–60% content of silver in the alloy, which corresponds to 100% filling. 3.2.3 XPS studies To substantiate the hypothesis about the electronic state of metal components and the presence of a geometric modification in the surface layer of catalysts, the surface-sensitive method of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used. This method provides important information on the surface charge state of elements and on their surface concentration, which is especially important for explaining the properties of heterogeneous catalysts. Three samples were chosen for the study: with equimolar ratio Pd:Ag = 1:1, with excess content of palladium (Pd:Ag = 1:0.25), and with excess content of modifier (Pd:Ag = 1:2). To obtain high-quality spectra, the concentration of deposited metals was increased so that the content of palladium was 3.5 wt.% and the content of modifier corresponded to the molar ratio Pd:Ag. The spectra of Pd3d and Ag3d regions for Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples are displayed in Fig. 5 . For a more correct comparison, spectra of the reference samples 3.5%Pd/Sibunit and 3.57%Ag/Sibunit were also measured. The binding energy (BE) of Pd3d5/2 core-level measured for Pd/Sibunit catalyst is 335.5 eV, which corresponds to dispersed metallic palladium. In the literature, binding energy of the Pd3d5/2 peak for metallic palladium is in the range of 334.8–335.4 eV [27,28,58–60]. A minor shift of Pd3d5/2 BE value to higher binding energies may be caused by the interaction of small palladium clusters with the carbon support via interatomic charge transfer to the support. It was shown in [61,62] that a positive shift of BE of the core levels occurs for small palladium clusters deposited on the conductive carbon material, so that the binding energy Pd3d5/2 can reach 336.4 eV. The position of the Pd3d5/2 peak for bimetallic Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples shifts toward low binding energies of 335.2–335.3 eV as compared to Pd/Sibunit, which testifies to the effect of electronic interaction between palladium and silver [27,60]. Besides, an increase in the silver content from Pd:Ag = 1:0.25 to Pd:Ag = 1:2 enhances this effect. As shown in Fig. 6 , the dependence of binding energy values on the content of metals is linear both in the case of Pd3d5/2 peak and in the case of Ag3d5/2. The Ag3d spectrum shows a shift of the Ag3d5/2 peak from 368.3 eV in Ag/Sibunit, which is typical for metallic silver [60,63], to 367.7 eV in the Pd–Ag(1:0.25)/Sibunit sample with the maximum Pd:Ag ratio. The presence of such shifts of photoelectron peaks testifies to the formation of alloyed bimetallic Pd–Ag nanoparticles [12,27,64,65]. The revealed shifts indicate that electron density is transferred from silver to more electronegative palladium atoms, which is consistent with changes in the binding energy for Pd3d5/2 [12]. However, it should be noted that a part of palladium and silver can exist not only as components of the alloy, but also as individual metallic nanoparticles. In particular, our earlier TEM study of 0.5%Pd–Ag(1:1)/Sibunit [38] showed that the system contains not only bimetallic nanoalloys, but also the larger particles of metallic silver with d av ∼ 9 nm, which agrees well with the XRD data obtained in this study. Along with this, it is impossible to reliably identify metals in monometallic state in Pd3d and Ag3d photoelectron spectra. As was supposed above, an increase in silver content of the catalysts leads to a growth of the Ag/C surface ratio and to a decrease in the surface concentration of palladium (Table 3 ). Consequently, the “dilution” of palladium atoms by atoms of the modifying element occurs both in the bulk of the bimetallic phase and on its surface. Herewith, the hydrogenation activity linearly decreases with a decrease in the surface concentration of palladium (not shown). Overall, it can be concluded that XPS analysis of the samples confirmed the hypothesis stating that the composition of Pd–Ag nanoalloys is related to the electronic state of metallic components and catalytic properties of samples in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of acetylene. Thus, the acetylene conversion and the activity of Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples decrease with an increase in the quantity of silver in the catalyst due to the formation of Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoalloys of different compositions. Nanoalloys enriched with silver have the lowest surface concentration of palladium and, accordingly, the lowest activity. Herewith, the modified samples exhibit better selectivity, which increases with increasing the silver content to the Pd:Ag = 1:2 due to the amplification of geometric and electronic factors. At first, the “dilution” of palladium atoms by silver in the structure of nanoalloy is accompanied by the expansion of the fcc palladium lattice and an increase in the distance between neighboring atoms of palladium from 2.72 in Pd/Sibunit to 2.76–2.85 Å depending on the bimetal composition. According to the literature data [6,66,67], such structure of active sites should hinder the strong multisite adsorption of acetylene and, accordingly, the occurrence of ethylene to ethane hydrogenation as a side reaction. Secondly, the electronic effect acts in the same direction. According to the XPS data, silver reduces the electron deficiency of palladium (a shift of the Pd3d peak to lower values), which facilitates the desorption of the target product and also causes an increase in selectivity [47]. It is possible that this factor may further contribute to a decrease in activity. 4 Conclusions The effect of silver on the structural, electronic and catalytic properties of Pd–Ag/Sibunit samples in the liquid-phase acetylene hydrogenation was studied. It was demonstrated by XRD and EXAFS that palladium and silver in the modified catalysts interact to produce bimetallic Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoparticles, the composition of which depends on the palladium to silver molar ratio taken at the synthesis step. According to the XPS, an increase in the amount of silver leads to the decrease in the surface palladium concentration which contributes to a decrease in activity. This is due to the varying of modifier enrichment degrees in the nanoalloys. The more silver contains Pd x Ag(1− x ) particle the more efficiently it modifies the electronic properties of palladium, causing an increase in selectivity. Based on the results obtained by XRD, EXAFS and XPS methods, Pd–Ag/Sibunit catalysts containing the bimetallic Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoparticles (x = 0.4−0.6) with the interatomic Pd-Pd distance of 2.80–2.85 Å and the Pd3d binding energy shift relative to the Pd/Sibunit of −0.2 to −0.3 eV possess the highest selectivity (up to 81%) at almost complete acetylene conversion (above 97%) in the liquid-phase acetylene hydrogenation to ethylene. coredata.dc:description: A series of bimetallic Pd–Ag catalysts supported on the carbon material Sibunit was synthesized for selective liquid-phase acetylene hydrogenation. Using XRD and EXAFS it was shown that palladium and silver in the 0.5% Pd–Ag/Sibunit can form bimetallic Pd x Ag(1− x ) nanoparticles with the composition depending on the Pd:Ag ratio. The active component of Pd–Ag(1:0.25)/Sibunit, Pd–Ag(1:1)/Sibunit and Pd–Ag(1:4)/Sibunit is represented by the particles of Pd0.74Ag0.26, Pd0.60Ag0.40 and Pd0.41Ag0.59 nanoalloys, respectively. An increase of the quantity of silver decreases the catalyst activity. The XPS study revealed that this phenomenon is caused by a decrease in the surface concentration of palladium (geometrical effect) and an increase in the degree of palladium electronic modification with silver (electronic effect). The latter exerts a beneficial effect on the reaction selectivity: as the Pd:Ag molar ratio is raised to 1:2, selectivity to ethylene increases to 81% (X > 97%), which exceeds 2.7-fold the selectivity of Pd/Sibunit.
coredata.dc:title: Liquid-phase acetylene hydrogenation over Ag-modified Pd/Sibunit catalysts: Effect of Pd to Ag molar ratio
